awd_titl_txt: Conference: EnviBayes Workshop on Complex Environmental Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop titled "EnviBayes Workshop on Complex Environmental Data" will be held in Fort Collins, Colorado on September 18-20, 2023. Environmental and ecological data are often complex and diverse. This complexity may arise from intricate data-generating mechanisms, such as the presence of many interacting species in an ecological study, or from structural dependence, such as correlation in space and time of air pollution measurements.  As such, analysis of environmental and ecological datasets may require specialized statistical and computational tools to appropriately capture and account for the complexity. While the ecological and environmental statistics community is not large, it is easy to become siloed in each of the respective sub-communities. However, the advances in modeling approaches and tools for one type of dependence (and data) can often be usefully extended to another type of dependence and have a large impact on multiple application areas. It can therefore benefit statisticians working with different facets of environmental and ecological data to interact with each other to propagate knowledge among our sub-communities for the increased advancement of all disciplines. The workshop will have the following major aims: i) to provide sub-communities within environmental and ecological statistics with a venue to share cutting-edge advancements within their own networks to further spark deeper knowledge gains; ii) to transfer knowledge between sub-communities and foster collaboration.

The program of the EnviBayes Workshop on Complex Environmental Data includes: i) Environmental Health and Epidemiology; ii) Data from Remote Sensing; iii) Models for Spatial and Temporal Dependence; iv) Multivariate and Spatial Extremes; v) Using Climate Models to Project Future Extremes; vi) Models for Animal Movement and Abundance; vii) Statistical Inference Related to Complex Computer Models. This project will encourage the participation of graduate students, early-career researchers, and members of groups under-represented in statistics. More details about the workshop can be found at: https://statistics.colostate.edu/envibayes-workshop/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The EnviBayes Workshop on Complex Environmental Data, hosted by Colorado State University in Fort Collins, CO, took place on September 18-20, 2023. The workshop served two purposes. The first was to provide sub-communities within environmental and ecological statistics with a venue to share cutting-edge advancements within their own networks to further spark deeper knowledge gains. The second was to transfer knowledge between sub-communities and foster collaboration.  This cross-communication included encouraging advances from the wider community of researchers in Bayesian analysis of complex datasets to percolate into the environmental domain. The workshop emphasized participation by graduate students and postdocs, fostering an exciting exchange of ideas that should continue into the future generations of statisticians.

The first day of the workshop featured a half-day short course centered on using and developing algorithms for hierarchical models with NIMBLE, including MCMC algorithms and Laplace approximation, taught by Chris Paciorek of UC Berkeley. The following two and one half days featured research talks on statistical methodology and applications related to the modelling of complex environmental data. These talks represented many topics and data types that fall within the area of environmental data, including environmental health and epidemiology, remote sensing, spatial and temporal dependence, and animal movement and abundance. Finally, there was a poster session on the evening of Monday, September 18, 2023.

The workshop included 82 registered participants, six of whom attended from countries outside the US.  Of the 82 participants, 32 were female, and 37 were graduate students or postdocs.  About 90% of the participants were from within academia, with 8 of them having primary affiliations in industry or national labs.  20 presented posters at the poster session.  A total of 13 junior researchers were able to participate thanks to funding from this award. In addition, due to matching contributions from the CSU Department of Statistics and College of Natural Sciences, 21 local students were able to participate in the workshop. The 37 graduate students and postdoctoral researchers from statistics and environmental/ecological sciences had the opportunity to present their work, and, importantly, make connections that will hopefully prove valuable in fostering productive collaborations down the road. These junior researchers also had close access to international leaders in both statistics andenvironmental/ecological sciences.
